title: NC Tutorial 1 (en)
data:
{"title":"NC Tutorial 1 (en)","nodes":{"1":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 0","x":27,"y":247,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Connect the 'out' output of the 'Sine' node to the 'left' and 'right' inputs of the 'AudioOut' node by clicking on the small yellow squares. 

Press the '▹Play' button at the top right of the window. Turn the 'freq' button with the mouse. Then press '◻︎Stop'."}},"2":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":658,"y":298,"ins":[["3",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"3":{"type":"Knob","name":"freq","x":520,"y":298,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":55,"maxVal":880,"value":220,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"5":{"type":"Notes","name":"Hello World","x":28,"y":25,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"    ---------------------------
   | First steps in NoiseCraft |
    ---------------------------

Some exercises in manipulating and exploring NoiseCraft functions (or 'nodes').

Move around the main window and the notes using the scroll bars.

All the nodes used in these exercises can be created by clicking on the background of the page and selecting them from the list. However, in this first tutorial, the focus will be on manipulating pre-existing nodes.


The notes associated with the exercises tell you more about the functionality of these nodes and about the theory of sound synthesis and music theory in general. These theories can be learned and refined later.

---------------------
Created by (a or not b)"}},"8":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 0","x":25,"y":446,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"The frequency 55, corresponds to an A(0)
The frequency 55*2=110 is an A(1)
The frequency 55*4=220 is an A(2)
The frequency 55*8=440 is an A(3)
The frequency 55*16=880 is an A(4)

The multiplication by two of a frequency allows to obtain the octave of the initial frequency. The frequencies are expressed in [Hz].

The spectrum of audible frequencies is generally located in humans between 20 and 20'000 [Hz]."}},"9":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 1","x":29,"y":673,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Move the 'AudioOut' node to the right of the 'Mul' node and connect the 'left' and 'right' inputs of the node to the 'out' output of the 'Mul' node.

Press the '▹Play' button at the top right of the window. Turn the synthesizer knobs to understand their effects. Add or remove points in the 'GateSeq'. Then press '◻︎Stop' when you are done playing."}},"10":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":662,"y":674,"ins":[["11",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"11":{"type":"Knob","name":"freq","x":532,"y":675,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":55,"maxVal":880,"value":220,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"13":{"type":"GateSeq","name":"GateSeq","x":531,"y":769,"ins":[["20",0],["19",0]],"inNames":["clock","gateT"],"outNames":["gate0"],"params":{},"numRows":1,"curPattern":0,"patterns":[[[1],[0],[0],[0],[1],[0],[0],[0],[1],[0],[0],[0],[0],[0],[1],[0]]]},"14":{"type":"ADSR","name":"ADSR","x":1046,"y":858,"ins":[["13",0],["15",0],["16",0],["17",0],["18",0]],"inNames":["gate","att","dec","sus","rel"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"15":{"type":"Knob","name":"Attack","x":534,"y":895,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.01,"maxVal":0.5,"value":0.01,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"16":{"type":"Knob","name":"Decay","x":607,"y":934,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.05,"maxVal":0.5,"value":0.11604101562500001,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"17":{"type":"Knob","name":"Sustain","x":681,"y":973,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.3813671875000011,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"18":{"type":"Knob","name":"Release","x":767,"y":1013,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.01,"maxVal":1,"value":0.23201523437500013,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"19":{"type":"Knob","name":"GateTime","x":422,"y":858,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.2927343750000006,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"20":{"type":"Clock","name":"Clock","x":422,"y":769,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":60,"maxVal":240,"value":60,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"21":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1053,"y":676,"ins":[["10",0],["14",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"22":{"type":"Scope","name":"Scope [0-1]","x":1166,"y":907,"ins":[["14",0]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1}},"23":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 1","x":30,"y":874,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"1. There is only one 'AudioOut' node per project since it is used to connect the synthesizer to the stereo output of your computer or sound card.

2. the 'ADSR' node allows you to create a volume envelope for the wave created by the 'Sine' node, by multiplying ('Mul') its amplitude by a value varying between 0 and 1. The shape of the envelope is determined by :

> 'attack': (triggered by the opening of the 'gate' = 1) is the time it takes for the envelope to rise to 1.

> 'decay' : the time it takes for the envelope to go back down to the 'sustain' value

> 'sustain' is the value at which the envelope stays until the gate is closed = 0 

> 'release' is the time it takes for the envelope to go back down to 0.

All the times indicated are in [s].

3. The 'clock' node allows to modify the speed of the sequencer. It determines its number of beats per minute [BPM]. The relevant beats are represented by wider black lines in the sequencer.

4. The value of the 'GateTime' button indicates the time in [s] during which the 'gate' will open (will be = 1) if a sequencer square is lit. It is the opening of this gate which triggers and determines the activity of the 'ADSR' node.

N.B. : If the duration of the opening of the gate is greater than the duration separating two sequencer squares, the second square will not activate the triggering of the ADSR.

N.B.2 : The two windows in which the "curves" appear are called "Scopes". Their scales can be set according to the signal that you want to visualize. It is possible to double-click on any "title bar" of a node to display its parameters. All this is not very important for the moment."}},"24":{"type":"Scope","name":"gate 0 [0-1]","x":1167,"y":770,"ins":[["13",0]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1}},"25":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 2","x":34,"y":1156,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Move the 'AudioOut' node to the right of the rightmost 'Add' node and connect the 'left' and 'right' inputs of the node to the 'out' output of the 'Add' node.

Select with your mouse (by drawing a red rectangle) the sequence (top) of nodes: '2'='Mul'-'vol'='Mul'.
The nodes become red. If you made a mistake, start again. Copy these nodes (cmd/ctrl+C) and put your mouse about 2 cm lower diagonally than the bottom right of the 'freq' button. This is where you will paste this sequence of nodes (cmd/ctrl+V).

If you made a mistake you can use (cmd/ctrl+Z) to undo the last operation(s). You can also select a node and delete it with the usual key. Furthermore, a sequence of nodes that has been cut can be moved with the mouse.

Once you have pasted this sequence of nodes :

1) connect the input 'in1' of the new node 'Mul' on the left to the output of the node-button 'freq'.
2) Connect the 'out' output of the new 'Mul' node (bottom right) to the 'in1' input of the 'Add' node.
3) Modify, by double-clicking inside the new node-constant '2' the value of this node by replacing it with 3.

Press the '▹Play' button at the top right of the window. Rotate the 'freq' and 'vol' buttons with the mouse. Then press '◻︎Stop'"}},"26":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":742,"y":1339,"ins":[["47",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"27":{"type":"Knob","name":"freq","x":447,"y":1358,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":55,"maxVal":880,"value":220,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"28":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":628,"y":1185,"ins":[["31",0],["27",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"29":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":731,"y":1186,"ins":[["28",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"30":{"type":"Add","name":"Add","x":1039,"y":1323,"ins":[["32",0],["26",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"31":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":561,"y":1205,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":2}},"32":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":913,"y":1187,"ins":[["29",0],["33",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"33":{"type":"Knob","name":"vol","x":836,"y":1225,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.1840234375000001,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"34":{"type":"Add","name":"Add","x":1158,"y":1378,"ins":[["30",0],null],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"46":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 2","x":37,"y":1367,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"You have just created an additive sound synthesis. The three 'Sine' wave generators are added thanks to the 'Add' nodes. Moreover, their respective frequencies are different, but in harmony. 

The second 'Sine' is indeed at the octave, since the value of the frequency has been multiplied by 2 (see Ex 0). It is the first natural "harmonic" of the base frequency (or the second "partial" harmonic if we consider the base frequency as the first partial harmonic of the considered sound). 

The third 'Sine' that you have created is at a frequency three times higher, which corresponds to the second natural harmonic of the base frequency: it is also the octave of the fifth of the base frequency. 

For example in the A major diatonic game: 

Deg FON 2. 3M  4. 5.  6M  7M
    A2  B  C#  D  E2  F#  G# 
HZ  220           330            
    A3  B  C#  D  E3  F#  G# 
HZ  440           660

note that E2 = A2 * 1,5 [the fifth]
and that E3 = A2 * 1.5 * 2 = A2 * 3
E3 is therefore the octave (*2) of the fifth (*1,5) of A2

see :
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmonic
for more details

The natural sound of a musical instrument can be analyzed as the addition of a very large quantity of these natural harmonics, each one having its own volume that can vary over time. This is what makes its particular "timbre".

see : 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timbre
For more details and criticism of this analysis.

What you have also just learned is that the 'Mul' node can be used in at least two ways. "In front of a wave generator like the 'Sine' node, it allows to multiply its frequency by a certain amount, which modifies the pitch. After the generator, it allows to modify its amplitude and thus its volume, here thanks to a button for example."}},"47":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":642,"y":1339,"ins":[["48",0],["27",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"48":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":575,"y":1359,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":1}},"49":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 3","x":37,"y":1793,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Move the 'AudioOut' node to the right of the rightmost 'Mul' node (with its 'OUT VOL' knob) as usual [scroll if necessary] and connect the 'left' and 'right' inputs of the node to the 'out' of the 'Mul' node as usual.

In this exercise, you will learn how to use the NoiseCraft 'MidiIn' node. It allows you to use the keys of your computer keyboard (A,S,D,F,...) [on my QWERTZ keyboard] or of your external Midi keyboard in order to play notes (input frequencies) of the synthesizer you are going to build.

The exercise will consist in using the material already tamed. You will 

1) copy and paste the ADSR nodes and its associated buttons (Attack, Decay, Sustain, Release) from exercise 1 and connect the 'gate' output of the 'MidiIn' to the 'gate' input of the 'ADSR', so that your keyboard will be able to activate the ADSR as long as you press a key.

2) You will copy the additive synthesizer created in exercise 2 and connect the 'in1' inputs of the three 'Mul' nodes to the 'freq' output of 'MidiIn'. In this way, your keyboard will be able to determine the base frequency that the synthesizer should play. The "freq" button which is now disconnected can be deleted by selecting it with the mouse and pressing the appropriate key.

3) You will create a 'Mul' node to the right of the last 'Add' node of your synthesizer by clicking on the background of the screen at this point and selecting the 'Mul' node in the list proposed.

3) You will connect the 'out' output of your last 'Add' node to the 'in0' input of the created 'Mul' and connect the 'out' output of your 'ADSR' to the 'in1' input of the same 'Mul'. Thus, your ADSR will create an amplitude envelope (volume) for your additive synthesizer when a key is pressed. 

4) You just have to connect the 'out' output of the 'Mul' created to the 'in0' input of the 'Mul' with its 'OUT VOL' button.

You now know how to press on Start and STOP to make your synthesizer work, don't you?

NB. The answer key of the exercise is just below."}},"51":{"type":"Scope","name":"freq[55-880]","x":509,"y":1801,"ins":[["87",0]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":55,"maxVal":880}},"52":{"type":"Scope","name":"gate[0-1]","x":514,"y":2030,"ins":[["87",1]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1}},"53":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1740,"y":1780,"ins":[null,["54",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"54":{"type":"Knob","name":"OUT VOL","x":1732,"y":1850,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":1,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"56":{"type":"MidiIn","name":"MidiIn","x":523,"y":2969,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":["freq","gate"],"params":{"octaveNo":5,"chanNo":null}},"57":{"type":"Scope","name":"freq[55-880]","x":519,"y":2824,"ins":[["56",0]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":55,"maxVal":880}},"58":{"type":"Scope","name":"gate[0-1]","x":524,"y":3053,"ins":[["56",1]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1}},"59":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":976,"y":2790,"ins":[["68",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"61":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":862,"y":2636,"ins":[["64",0],["56",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"62":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":965,"y":2637,"ins":[["61",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"63":{"type":"Add","name":"Add","x":1273,"y":2774,"ins":[["65",0],["59",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"64":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":795,"y":2656,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":2}},"65":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1147,"y":2638,"ins":[["62",0],["66",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"66":{"type":"Knob","name":"vol","x":1070,"y":2676,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.7366015625000005,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"67":{"type":"Add","name":"Add","x":1392,"y":2829,"ins":[["63",0],["73",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"68":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":876,"y":2790,"ins":[["69",0],["56",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"69":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":809,"y":2810,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":1}},"70":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":854,"y":2946,"ins":[["72",0],["56",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"71":{"type":"Sine","name":"Sine","x":957,"y":2947,"ins":[["70",0],null],"inNames":["freq","sync"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{"minVal":-1,"maxVal":1}},"72":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":787,"y":2966,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":3}},"73":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1139,"y":2948,"ins":[["71",0],["74",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"74":{"type":"Knob","name":"vol","x":1062,"y":2986,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.15964843750000046,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"75":{"type":"ADSR","name":"ADSR","x":1271,"y":3121,"ins":[["56",1],["76",0],["77",0],["78",0],["79",0]],"inNames":["gate","att","dec","sus","rel"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"76":{"type":"Knob","name":"Attack","x":759,"y":3158,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.01,"maxVal":0.5,"value":0.01,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"77":{"type":"Knob","name":"Decay","x":832,"y":3197,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.05,"maxVal":0.5,"value":0.11604101562500001,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"78":{"type":"Knob","name":"Sustain","x":906,"y":3236,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":0.3813671875000011,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"79":{"type":"Knob","name":"Release","x":992,"y":3276,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0.01,"maxVal":1,"value":0.23201523437500013,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"80":{"type":"Scope","name":"Scope [0-1]","x":1391,"y":3170,"ins":[["75",0]],"inNames":[""],"outNames":[],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1}},"81":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1523,"y":2829,"ins":[["67",0],["75",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"82":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1653,"y":2829,"ins":[["81",0],["83",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"83":{"type":"Knob","name":"OUT VOL","x":1645,"y":2899,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":1,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"86":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 3","x":40,"y":1999,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"The button "OUT VOL" allows to control the output volume of the synthesizer. Thereafter it will always be useful to have a button of this type at the end of the chain (associated with its 'Mul') so as to be able to quickly lower the volume of your synthesizer in order not to hurt your ears.

If you use the keys of your computer, to play notes (A,W,S,E,D,F,T,G,H,U,J,K) [on a QWERTZ keyboard] you can go up or respectively down one octave, by pressing the X and Z keys of your keyboard.

If you have done the exercises correctly, you have now understood the essential functions of NoiseCraft. The sound generated so far is not very rich, but it is just a start. In the following tutorials you will see how to use other sound generators, how to combine them, how to use filters, and how to automate or not some of your sound modulations."}},"87":{"type":"MidiIn","name":"MidiIn","x":513,"y":1948,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":["freq","gate"],"params":{"octaveNo":5,"chanNo":null}},"88":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 3 bis","x":63,"y":2898,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Answers to exercise 3 (without 'AudioOut')"}},"89":{"type":"AudioOut","name":"AudioOut","x":925,"y":302,"ins":[null,null],"inNames":["left","right"],"outNames":[],"params":{}}}}
